article_title: Texas Senate lays out prerequisites for Medicaid expansion
article_text:
Texas Senate lays out prerequisites for Medicaid expansion

AUSTIN - The Texas Senate on Monday gave the federal government what amounted to an ambitious list of preconditions for any negotiations about expanding Medicaid in the state, demanding President Barack Obama loosen regulations and make recipients here work and pay premiums and missed-appointment fees before any widening of eligibility is considered.

article_metadata.description: AUSTIN - The Texas Senate on Monday gave the federal government what amounted to an ambitious list of preconditions for any negotiations about expanding Medicaid in the state, demanding President Barack Obama loosen regulations and make recipients here work and pay premiums and missed-appointment fees before any widening of eligibility is considered.  "[...] we receive the kind of federal flexibility we're calling for here today - the kind needed to fundamentally reform Texas's existing Medicaid program in a way that preserves it for our most vulnerable Texans - any expansion of Medicaid in Texas is simply not worth discussing," said Sen. Charles Schwertner, R-Georgetown, a doctor who chairs the chamber's Health and Human Services Committee, during a packed news conference at the state Capitol.  "The federal government is committed to working with states to design programs uniquely their own, while maintaining essential health benefits guaranteed under the Affordable Care Act and other key consumer protections consistent with the law," spokesman Aaron Albright said.  In addition to the added requirements for Medicaid recipients, the list of requests includes creating customized benefit packages for individual needs and exempting the state from regulations that require doctors to continue treating Medicaid patients and hospitals to temporarily sign up babies for the program who are likely to be eligible.  "The proposal to squeeze a few extra dollars out of low-income children, pregnant women, the elderly, and Texans with disabilities, announced the same week the Senate plans to consider tax cuts for some of the state's largest businesses, represents the wrong priorities for Texas," said the coalition, Cover Texas Now, in a statement.
article_metadata.author.name: By Brian M. Rosenthal
